en: bloodworm (local usage in South Africa for Arenicola loveni, although lugworm is the worldwide English vernacular for genus Arenicola)

texts.shortText: Very large, well-known worm that digs deep U-shaped burrows in estuaries, lagoons and sheltered sandy beaches. Body tough and cylindrical, dark brown to black with a rough, round, balloon-like proboscis that can be inflated or withdrawn. Anterior section of the body with tufts of setae and branched red gills on each segment. Thinner tail section lacking gills or obvious setae.
Body length typically about 200 mm, but can exceed 500 mm long.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Durban.

Digs deep U-shaped burrows in fine sediments in sheltered sites. The head end of the burrow is visible as a funnel-like depression and the tail end as a small cone. Water is drawn though the burrow by peristaltic movements of the worm’s body and this action both oxygenates the sediment and pulls in detrital particles, which accumulate in a feeding zone around the head of the animal. Here the water movement and bacterial action help decomposes the detritus, making it more digestible.
Eggs and sperm are released into the water and develop into planktonic larvae.
A second smaller species, Gilchrist’s bloodworm Abarenicola gilchristi also occurs in the same region and the ridges on each segment are more widely separated ventrally.
